title: Best Moisturizers for Dry, Oily, and Combination Skin

content: With all the various products on the market, it can be overwhelming to choose a moisturizer that fits your skin care goals. Knowing your skin type is crucial to determining your skin’s moisturizing needs. I recommend the following steps to determine your unique skin type.
Step 1: Wash your face with a gentle soap-free cleanser. I recommend CeraVe Foaming Facial Cleanser.
Step 2: Pat dry your face with a clean washcloth. Do not apply any products.
Step 3: Wait 30 minutes and assess your skin. How does it feel? Tight? Normal? Still shiny?
Skin Types
There are four main skin types:
Dry: You have a rough texture and tightness after cleansing; skin that overall appears dull and under-hydrated.
Oily: You have shiny, greasy, and noticeably large pores.
Combination: You have dryness on the cheeks and excess oil production in the T-zone (forehead, nose, and chin) or increased oil production in high humidity.
Normal: Your skin is balanced, with no blemishes, no stinging, and no sensitivity.

content: Within the major skin types, there are other associated skin type subcategories. For example, mature skin, which often requires heavier, more moisturizing products, and acne-prone skin, which should avoid oil-based products.
Dry Skin

Dry skin can be a result of genetic conditions, like eczema, which occur due to the absence of proteins and various substances that protect against trans-epidermal water loss. To restore the skin barrier, products that contain ceramides are essential. I recommend CeraVe Moisturizing Cream. This is oil-free, so it’s also safe to use for acne-prone skin.

Dry skin can also develop over time from environmental causes, like dry climates or medications that dry out your skin’s natural oil production. Opt for products with humectants, like hyaluronic acid, to draw water into the skin and aid in moisturizing. I recommend CeraVe Hydrating Hyaluronic Acid Face Serum. Additionally, occlusive moisturizers, like Vaseline or Aquaphor, are also helpful to retain the body’s natural moisturizing capabilities.
Oily Skin

Oily skin is a product of overactive oil glands. While this aids in natural skin hydration, it can also make your skin more prone to breakouts. Additionally, excess oil production can make pores look more prominent, a common complaint I hear from my oil-prone patients. Oily skin is often genetic and difficult to control without prescription medications from your dermatologist. To control the oil, I recommend gel-based moisturizers that offer hydration, while not worsening the oil: Products like Neutrogena Hydro Boost Gel-Cream or CeraVe Ultra-Light Moisturizing Gel. Also, always opt for oil-free products, including serums and sunscreens.

sections.heading: Combination Skin
content: Combination skin usually has oil production along the T-zone and more dryness on the cheeks. The approach for combination skin is to focus on reducing oil production. Products containing retinoids and their derivatives are essential in decreasing oil production over prolonged use. I recommend CeraVe Skin Renewing Retinol Serum. This powerhouse also contains both hyaluronic acid and niacinamide, which also has some mild lightening properties.
Sensitive Skin

People with sensitive skin usually have redness and complain about a stinging sensation. This is typical of hyperreactivity due to environmental causes or irritating skin care products. Typical sensitive skin patients may also have underlying conditions, such as rosacea or eczema (atopic dermatitis). Microscopically, there is typically an impaired barrier that causes significant irritation to develop. I recommend products that are absent of harsh chemicals or have limited amounts of inactive ingredients. Sensitive skin care lines, like Vanicream, are all-encompassing and offer many staple skin care products to choose from.
Taking time to discover your skin type will help you choose products that give you the best results. And basic rule of thumb: It if burns, do not use it.
